prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in physics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in physics would. What is the hundreds digit of $2011^{2011}$?
gpt_response:
To find the hundreds digit of $2011^{2011}$, we will first need to find the remainder of $2011^{2011}$ when divided by 1000. We can then determine the hundreds digit from the remainder.

Since we are only interested in the hundreds digit, we will only consider the last three digits of $2011^{2011}$. 

To find the last three digits, we will take the last three digits of 2011 (which is 011) and raise it to the power of 2011 using modular arithmetic.

To make our calculations easier, we will first find the cycle of powers of 11 modulo 1000:

$11^1 \equiv 011\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^2 \equiv 121\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^3 \equiv 331\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^4 \equiv 641\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^5 \equiv 051\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^6 \equiv 561\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^7 \equiv 771\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^8 \equiv 881\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^9 \equiv 991\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^{10} \equiv 901\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

After observing the cycle, we see that the last three digits of $11^{10}$ is 901.

To find the last three digits of $2011^{2011}$, we divide 2011 by 10 to find the remainder:

$2011 \equiv 11\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

Now, we raise 11 to the power of the remainder (11) modulo 1000:

$11^{11} \equiv 011\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

Therefore, the last three digits of $2011^{2011}$ is 011.

Since we are looking for the hundreds digit, the number 2011 raised to a power with last three digits of 011 would result in a hundreds digit of 4. 

Therefore, the hundreds digit of $2011^{2011}$ is 4.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 6?: To find the hundreds digit of $2011^{2011}$, we will first need to find the remainder of $2011^{2011}$ when divided by 1000. We can then determine the hundreds digit from the remainder.

Since we are only interested in the hundreds digit, we will only consider the last three digits of $2011^{2011}$. 

To find the last three digits, we will take the last three digits of 2011 (which is 011) and raise it to the power of 2011 using modular arithmetic.

To make our calculations easier, we will first find the cycle of powers of 11 modulo 1000:

$11^1 \equiv 011\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^2 \equiv 121\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^3 \equiv 331\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^4 \equiv 641\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^5 \equiv 051\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^6 \equiv 561\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^7 \equiv 771\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^8 \equiv 881\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^9 \equiv 991\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

$11^{10} \equiv 901\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

After observing the cycle, we see that the last three digits of $11^{10}$ is 901.

To find the last three digits of $2011^{2011}$, we divide 2011 by 10 to find the remainder:

$2011 \equiv 11\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

Now, we raise 11 to the power of the remainder (11) modulo 1000:

$11^{11} \equiv 011\ (\text{mod}\ 1000)$

Therefore, the last three digits of $2011^{2011}$ is 011.

Since we are looking for the hundreds digit, the number 2011 raised to a power with last three digits of 011 would result in a hundreds digit of 4. 

Therefore, the hundreds digit of $2011^{2011}$ is 4.
